Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor has set aside open office hours throughout the week.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story: I stared at my calendar, anxiety prickling at my skin. My mentor’s office hours were a rare window—she’d made it clear that her time was precious, and I was lucky to have her guidance. I’d promised myself I’d show up, prepared and respectful, never wasting a minute. But as I dialed into my telemarketing shift, the phone lines lit up. Prospect after prospect grilled me with technical questions about our new service, questions my script barely touched. My supervisor expected me to handle every objection, to keep callers engaged, to never say, “I don’t know.” I glanced at the clock. If I left now, I’d make my mentor’s office hours, but I’d be abandoning my post, letting down my team and risking my stats. If I stayed, I’d miss my chance to connect with my mentor, maybe for weeks. My chest tightened as I weighed the demands—be the reliable mentee, or the dependable telemarketer. Both roles pulled at me, and I felt myself caught in the middle, unable to satisfy either without disappointing someone.
